Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Approximate optimization: Algorithms, Hardness, and Integrality Gaps

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Optimization problems, where the goal is to find a solution subject to some constraints that maximizes or minimizes a certain objective value, are ubiquitous in computing. As an overwhelming majority of optimization problems are NP-hard to solve optimally, one widely studied approach is to settle for approximately optimal solutions with provable guarantees on quality. The overarching goal in the theory of approximate optimization is to identify, for broad classes of optimization problems, the best approximation factor achievable efficiently. This study has two sides that go hand-in-hand, the design of efficient approximation algorithms, and complementary hardness results establishing limits to the best approximation possible. One of the most widely employed approaches to design approximation algorithms is via convex programming relaxations such as linear or semidefinite programs. So a third intertwined aspect is to understand the power and limitations of such tools for important optimization problems.

Research on this topic has made huge strides, and for a broad class of problems called constraint satisfaction problems, a common meeting ground of all these aspects has been uncovered, in the form of a canonical semidefinite program achieving the best possible approximation ratio in a unified manner. This theory, however, relies on the unproven Unique Games Conjecture (UGC), and also doesn't extend to various other important settings. This project focuses on a carefully conceived collection of fundamental research directions that are germane given our current understanding of the approximability landscape. Topics studied will include approaches to bypass the reliance on the UGC where possible, the complexity of approximately solving problems where a perfectly satisfying assignment exists (a setting that is not at all captured by the UGC), and a promising new direction where the notion of approximation is not in the number of constraints satisfied but rather in how strongly the constraints are satisfied. The project will aim to advance the frontiers of the subject by harnessing the confluence of the three aspects: algorithms, hardness, and mathematical programming, that together bear upon this rich subject. In particular, the project will investigate the power of semidefinite programs in certifying properties of random graphs and matrices, as well as their limitations in the form of integrality gaps as prognosis of the intractability of problems whose status is otherwise open or only known under the UGC.

The proposed research will shed light on the approximability of basic optimization problems that abstract some of the core computational tasks arising in practice. The research and outreach activities will aim to foster a cross-fertilization of ideas between the approximation and constraint satisfaction communities. On the education front, the project will train and mentor graduate students and provide a stimulating research environment for them. The research will balance the long term and general agenda of advancing the frontiers of the subject with the investigation of precisely stated open questions that are yet to receive the thorough investigation they deserve. The research findings, as appropriate, will be integrated into a novel course highlighting the emerging confluence of algorithms, hardness results, and integrality gaps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optimization problems, where the goal is to find a solution that maximizes or minimizes a desired objective value while obeying certain stipulated constraints, are ubiquitous. Unfortunately, more often than not they are also very hard and require an impossibly large amount of resources to solve to optimality. One of the widely studied approaches to cope with this intractability is to settle for approximation algorithms, which efficiently find solutions with provable guarantees on quality relative to the optimum. The quest for such algorithms is complemented by a hardness of approximation side that investigates the fundamental limits of efficient algorithms. The hardness aspect in turn falls in two categories. One line of work studies the limits of common algorithmic techniques, most notably the efficacy of convex relaxations of the problem that are the workhorse in many powerful algorithms (these are called ?gap? results). The other obtains complexity-theoretic intractability results (NP-hardness or similar) via reductions. Recent progress has enhanced our understanding of the confluence of algorithms, hardness reductions, and integrality gaps. The project studied the complexity of approximating several important classes of problems in this backdrop, with particular focus on delineating the boundary between algorithms and hardness results.

One class of problems with very large gaps in our understanding are problems on continuous inputs, such as optimizing a polynomial function over the unit sphere (in Euclidean or some other norm). The project investigated several problems of this flavor, obtaining algorithmic guarantees based on a powerful class of convex relaxations called sum-of-squares semidefinite programs, along with some complementary gap results. The investigation also led to the first NP-hardness results for approximating hypercontractive norms, a class of problems of special significance that mark our frontiers of understanding in many contexts.  The project made substantial progress on various aspects of constraint satisfaction problems (CSP), a rich and important framework that have spurred some of the most far-reaching advances in the theory of computing. An exciting direction of inquiry spurred by the project is an extension of the CSP framework to promise CSP (PCSP), where one seeks a different form of approximation, wherein the algorithm finds a solution obeying a relaxed version of the stipulated constraints. The project laid the groundwork for the study of PCSP using the algebraic/polymorphic approach, which has already led to a flurry of activity. In particular, notable progress has been made on some longstanding questions concerning graph and hypergraph coloring.

In terms of broader impact, the research and outreach activities fostered a cross-fertilization of ideas between the approximation and constraint satisfaction dichotomy communities, which till recently largely progressed independently with little interaction.  In particular, multiple workshops bringing together researchers from these backgrounds were organized, and the resulting correspondence and collaborations have led to a powerful synthesis of the algebraic approach to CSP with optimization techniques on the algorithmic side, and with the probabilistic checkable proof machinery on the hardness side. On the education front, the project trained and mentored several graduate students, provided a stimulating research environment that involved them in all aspects of the research, and led to multiple high quality Ph.D. dissertations. It also formed the basis of some extremely successful and award-winning undergraduate research experiences, and the involved students all went on to graduate school at top institutions.
